Text: Forever changing the course of history for kickstarting mainstream summer blockbuster films, Jaws set the standard for being the highest grossing film of its time and one of the finest achievements in bringing killer sharks to the big screen. After its success, several sequels have followed, all of which failed to reach the same level of quality as the original, as well as toys, a theme park ride at Universal Studios, and even its own line of spoofs taking a similar approach in depicting killer animals. Despite carrying a PG rating at the time, this is a film that feels like a hard R rating due to the level of blood and mature themes featured throughout and targets more towards young adults.

I thought that it was a very good movie. It kept you on the edge of your seat most of the time and the characters did a nice job of carrying out their roles in the movie. I just finished up watching all three movies of Jaws and I found them  interesting but, Jaws 1 of course took top billing and the other two, well they kind of lost ground in trying to remain as being as effective as Jaws 1. Jaws II  wasn't bad but, by the time Jaws lll came along it really went I thought downhill! Jaws III was to me just another movie about a shark and not as exciting I thought! However, I did enjoy revisiting the movies once again.

This movie is all right, I personally love the 2017 Kong: skull island movie much more but this one is still good, I wish there was more time on the island and less time on the boat and in New York. The main problem is is just how long it is. But all in all its a good movie.

Saw Rain Man again last night. I have seen it a few times. It is still fresh and relevant after all these years. It hasn't really aged. Tom Cruise gives an excellent performance of a selfish greedy man who comes into his own as he cares for Raymond and comes to realise his own failure in keeping in touch with his father and his selfish ways. By the end of the movie Charlie is not the same person and is no longer just interested in the financial gain. It is a great example of a character arc. What can you say about Dustin Hoffman and his devotion to the role and staying on point throughout the whole movie. His body language and the tilting of his head. This movie was so satisfying. Funny heartfelt and totally authentic. Totally believable ending. Great reference to Qantas never having an accident. We see Charlie in a totally different light at the end of the movie. Mature and enlightened.

The movie was enjoyable and interesting. It had interesting points in the direction and script. But it was very Hollywood. Apart from the good acting of the actors and the finesse of the director, it has the stereotype of Hollywood.

Ah. Iron Man 2008. Aka Not Only The First Iron Man Film In the Franchise, but also the Very First MCU Film and where it all began. This was released in 2008. Does it still hold up today in 2021 13 years later? Well. Yes Actually. In fact, this is a very Enjoyable film Where It tells a story Of Iron Man Gaining a Suit to fight against Evil and becomes “IronMan” For the film itself, I’m giving it some major praise because the film itself was Put together very well. The technology of this film feels like a future generation of our lives in the 2050’s. Which sets up a very good tone of showing the other suit wearing that Tony Stark uses in his home. Robert Downey Jr Truly shows off how well An Iron man actor can truly Be. In this film, he’s just as phenomenal as some of the other movies that Robert Played in. There are also some other very good actors like Jon Favreau, Gwyneth Paltrow and of course Samuel L. Jackson(Nick Furry). The Movie’s CGI Was Also Portrayed extremely well. It looked very realistic with those flight scenes. The Music Score was phenomenal, the action Sequences were amazing, the post credits scene was amazing. With Nick Furry hinting us that iron man isn’t the only avenger. And Finally, this is amazing cuz it (1) tells the origin of iron man, and (2) It was were it all began. My Complaints about this film is that we don’t get to the actual iron man suit playing around halfway through the movie, some of the scenes kinda failed in comparison to the comic’s, the Dialogue was humorous(mind you, this for most of the other marvel films) and this maybe just me, but I feel Nick Fury Should have gotten some more screen time since I love Nick Fury. A lot. Despite that, Iron Man is truly a fairly great film that started this franchise. Although there are some better ones out there that you should be on the lookout for. Nevertheless, I highly recommend this to any Iron Man Fans Out there.

Even though it's not THE most cinematic experience like the other MCU movies, it's still a straight-up masterpiece as the MCU's 1st movie. I only give it 3 stars because I hate the villain and the extremely long (to me) love scenes between Pepper and Tony. But the gags are just as good as the special effects, and Iron Man is an awesome, but not perfect, cinematic event. GO MARVEL!

These are one of those movies which are silent and have no redemption, just cold thriller no banging background music. Denis's film style is easy to catch, with wide shots trying to capture the environment in the background, and kind of feels like a documentary. The story is shown to us through Emily Blunt's character 'Kate', and from that pov, we don't know what's actually happening or what's coming next, just feels real. Because Kate is never shot anybody and worst of worst brutal scenes so it actually feels terrifying when we see the things which shock us for a moment, I Denis's movie never hides anything, no matter how brutal it is, and tells a lot through simple visuals. I was shocked to see Jon Bernthal, it reminded me of Marvel-Netflix's Punisher, lol. I'm recently watching crime-thriller movies, maybe because I like how characters act in certain situations. I'll recommend this if you want to watch but it feels slow and maybe you'll feel bored because most of the we are just following the character who doesn't know what's next and where she's headed. So if you like watching crime thrillers, probably this you can watch them.

There is sometimes a moment when after so many other previous iterations of the same story comes one that stands out for truly looking deeper into a character than all others combined. This was easily one of those few. Director Matt Reeves came onto this project with probably one of the most original approaches to a superhero I’ve ever seen. He stuck with a 70s dark cinema technique blended with an 80s- early 90s- comic book writing and pacing style that really pulls you in and feels worth the ticket and fun. The cinematography is beautiful and well-thought out through most of the film, the Batmobile scene was sublime, the score (Nirvana!! Need I say more?), and every character had incredible depth that can be hard for some directors. And the biggest selling point? Batman is finally the detective here!! He’s in crime scenes, uses tech to find clues, even uses people to help him figure out the mystery. It’s a great feeling when after all the Batman Detective comics you’ve read as a kid finally hit the big screen in the coolest way possible.

Matt Reeves has always managed to stamp a distinctive storytelling and aesthetic signature to each of his works, despite remaking classics like the “Planet of the Apes” franchise and continues on the same vein now, with “Batman”. Robert Pattinson’s rendering of the Dark Knight is everything we wanted Ben Affleck’s broken, cynical and disillusioned mature Batman to be and so much more!
I can see why this is a bit of a cult classic.  A 2020 remake would be incredible.  Gave 4 out of 5 stars due to the time the movie was made, 1979.  Film was much different then

Iron Man 2 isn't as good as the first film but it's still a lot of fun.  There's twice as much action, twice as much jokes and introduces us to one my favourite underutilized Marvel heroes, War Machine.  The story is alright, pretty believable if not slightly slow and sadly Mickey Rourke as Whiplash is a pretty dull character, although his action scenes are still fun.  I'm terms of its place in the MCU it's sort of forgettable because story-wise nothing that happens here really carries over to any other films.  Taken as a standalone film however, I still really enjoyed it.  It does come across as more cartoony and less serious than the first film but I didn't mind it as much as others apparently.  One of my favourite scenes was Whiplash making his entrance at the Monaco Grand Prix and cutting cars in half with his arc-powered whips.  The character may have been dull but he caused a lot of damage and he looked cool with his orange overalls burning off!

The best movie ever, it's a GREAT movie! Marlon Brando gives a great performance as Don Vito Corleone, so does Al Pacino and Robert Duvall, it is the best drama in history, it is a classic! I absolutely loved the story! A Mafia known as the "Godfather" who hands over his criminal empire to his son, Micheal (Al Pacino) and things go wrong! Brilliant! SO brilliant! It's very long but very good, Francis Ford Coppola, thank you So much for directing this masterpiece back in the 70s,  and bringing the best actors: Pacino and Brando, especially Robert Duvall ! I wish that there were more but to-be-fair, if they brought more, the newer movies would probably be like 1% on Rotten Tomatoes! And also, fun fact: Francis Ford Coppola is still alive and 80 years old right now! It's good to hear that, man!

This might quite possibly be the best movie ever made. It has completely replaced Terminator 2 and Pulp Fiction as my favourite film. Its combination of great acting, cinematography, dialogue, storytelling and other things make this movie a perfect movie. It also manages to keep a very slow, steady pace without being boring, which is not an easy feat to achieve.

I purchased this movie along with the Godfather 2, 8 months ago back in April. For some reason, I kept putting this franchise off to watch other movies. Last night I finally decided to sit down and watch this incredible movie and it simply did NOT disappoint. From the opening scene to the last, I was constantly at the edge of my seat. This is now my favorite movie of all time. Watching the transformation of Michael from being a family man to slowly becoming a cold blooded, heartless killer was spectacular. The baptism scene finale along with the restaurant scene built so much suspense and I loved it. And of course Marlon Brando's role as Vito was amazing as well, along with James Caan, John Cazale, and Robert Duvall. I'm going to watch Godfather Part 2 in a couple of days and I've heard a lot of great things about it, many say its better than the original and I'm excited to see what happens. Overall the original is amazing and spectacular and I strongly recommend watching this at least once in your lifetime.
Scott Pilgrim vs. the World is a sensory masterpiece. The film is pure fun, creative, and full of satisfying action. This is how graphic novel adaptations should be done!

I really wanted to like this movie. It does some impressive things visually and is pretty well edited. But I can't for the life of me understand how something can be so bold, energetic, and conceptually daring while at the same time so mundane and lifeless. It could've been a much better film if the characters/acting weren't so dull. I feel like they leaned into the whole "depressed 20-somethings youth" vibe too much, and everyone just seems way too careless and monotonous for the action-packed fever dream of a film they're in.

After an astounding Whiplash (2014), director Damien Chazelle is back with yet another awe-inspiring tale of music and passion in the form of La La Land which stars Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone in lead roles. As magical as the title suggests, the film takes viewers on a phenomenal ride of love and ambition but without turning a blind eye to the harsh realities of life. Why I say this is because the choices the characters make in this film have realistic and often heart-breaking consequences.

Very good, but not Wow! Ho hum.  Ok, so, it’s hard to underestimate all the hype & raves surrounding this long awaited sequel & as a result of that hype, I expected it to completely “knock my socks off” & blow my mind. It did neither, but it is, however, very, very good.

Martin Scorsese really is in his wheelhouse when it comes to crime films and "Casino" is the type of gangster film that, on the surface, looks like a grand epic with a luxurious coat of paint but in reality is a dark tale of greed, excess, and violence that highlights the corruption of the Gaming Commission in Las Vegas during the 1970s and 80s. Based on the book from author Nicholas Pileggi that's based on true events.

True story.... I believe it. I no longer have to question how hard it would be to have the job of a Casino owner; this movie showed me. How fast things spun into disaster with Sam's wife, best friend, and the entire casino! The resulting mayhem is an absolute mess contributed with greed, thirst for power, violence, betrayal, dishonesty, and a lot of lives taken in some gruesome manners. Beyond flawless acting from the iconic duo Robert De Niro and Joe Pesci.
While "North by Northwest" is my favorite Alfred Hitchcock film, his 1954 classic "Rear Window" is a very close second as it's a masterclass in audience manipulation.

As far back as I can remember, I always wanted to be a gangster.” Martin Scorsese’s woozy, dizzy adaptation of Nicholas Pileggi’s slice-of-Mafia-life book Wiseguy is many things: a social anthropology study, an epic look at the American Dream, a coked-up nightmare, a nostalgic look back at an age when made men were made men, a head-spinning display of virtuosic filmmaking, the blueprint for the modern organized-crime saga.

This is my favorite "Mob Film" of all-time. It's a somewhat true story about a real mob family and the people in that family. "Some stories were exaggerated", according to the director and Henry Hill, who was played by Ray Liotta in the film, "but it is still 95% accurate". Joe Pesci's performance as Tommy was incredible. He was my favorite character to be honest, he was extremely violent and sadistic, but also hilarious.

Well, there are “Spaghetti Westerns”, and then there are Sergio Leone’s Spaghetti Westerns. His are in a class by themselves. The directorial genius of Leone and an understated, yet riveting musical score by Enio Moriconi work in perfect tandem to create an unsettling, disturbing mood against a backdrop of lawlessness and grit.

Such a beautiful film with a wonderful musical background  ( Morricone at his best)  but so difficult in sequence! All those episodes going back and forth were quite a headache for me!! I must  confess that I like a story to start at the beginning, develop and draw to a  close.  A lot of the acting is superb.The violence is quite unnerving but I am mature enough not to be too  shocked.

An incredible film,indeed! The entire Cast,Writers,Director(s),the entire Film crew,and location scouts,all did an amazing job! Beautiful acting and time pieces,that definitely garnered and generated Academy Awards nods during the 1984 Academy Awards show! “Once Upon A Time In America” is an outstanding film! Absolutely All of the actors and actresses are phenomenal in this picture.

Home Alone, is a spectale & a classic like no other. It isn't perfect, the second act does drag a little, the scenes with "Angels with Filthy Souls" is clever and funny, the opening scene with Kevin enjoying being home alone and third act is a little kiddish, going from prat fall to something out of a kid friendly SAW and this movie's strong point for comedy is the Wet Bandits, with there physical and visual comedy. The movie is weak with jokes but comedy is there.

Oh My Gosh, This movie 100% justifies to the genre. Every bit of second, its thrilling,  Its  a  perfect Eroctic crime thriller. Brilliant Screenplay and wonderful direction, Really loved the making, every intimate scene has own relevance , and it shows the drive of a killer, There is lot space for debate about the performance of the lead Hero and Heroine, I liked both. This movie is a perfect crime thriller, and the climax was stunning, ! Wow.

Although there is a slow start to "Cape Fear," ultimately, it pays off. Martin's direction was top tier, maybe the peak of his career, as he managed to pull the audience in and skillfully rest the suspense on the watcher's shoulders and chest.De Niro- what can I say? He never disappoints! I have yet to see him in a movie that didn't sell him. Everything from the accent (which was undeniably amazing), to the wardrobe, to the accessories severely made his role.

Great 1990s thriller movie, it really gives you incite into the perspective people had on lawyers and what they’re mandated to do for their clients despite their own personal opinions. It was awe inspiring to see Jessica Lange, Robert De Niro, and Juliette Lewis in a film from almost 30 years ago really pull their roles together to create such a riveting story.

Quentin Tarantino's "Pulp Fiction" stands as a timeless masterpiece that effortlessly blends razor-sharp dialogue, unforgettable characters, dark humor, and a non-linear structure. With its irreverent attitude towards extreme violence, the film manages to captivate audiences while offering a thought-provoking exploration of nihilism and human nature. From its stellar performances to its meticulously woven narratives, "Pulp Fiction" remains a cinematic triumph that continues to enthrall and entertain.
This is Quentin Tarantino at his finest! Engaging characters; non-stop action; and intricately woven individual stories that produce a mesmerizing whole..
I was watching this movie for the 3rd time, a couple of days ago & it still had the same impact on me, what it had on the first watch !!

moronic, hokey, musical about a love story between a 50s greaser and a australian transfer student and the mischievous shenanigans that happens to them. pleasant, never boring but this is not the sound of music but for fans of john and travolta, it delivers. great race cars also. a 7 out of 10.

Alfred Hitchcock is responsible for making my favorite film of his in "Rear Window," a true gem of suspense and thrills but his 1958 masterpiece "Vertigo" is neck and neck with that film. Not being a well received film from the master of suspense during its initial release, over time it has been deemed his best work and for great reason as it's an expertly crafted psychological mystery that tells the story of the dangers of "love."

James Stewart is, of course, brilliant. American man to the core and yet, here he is, a failure of a cop. A man who failed in his physicality, which is just not allowed in Hollywood, because men don't fail - or if they do, it's part of their journey to succeed. Well, Hitchcock wasn't American, and Stewart - considered the embodiment of a certain kind of American man - was an actor, and in his own way, subversive. He spends a lot of this movie trying to be the Stewart we think we know - funny, wry, principled - but there is a strong undercurrent of frustration, limitation and fear.

This is a Western’s Western: an immovable epic film that has become a timeless class in the pantheon of cinema exploring ‘The Old West’. This was easily Sergio Leone’s masterpiece made during his masterfully impactful career; from A Fistful of Dollars to Once Upon a Time in America, the man became one of Italy’s hottest directors from 1964 to his untimely passing in 1989. It may have been a career short-lived compared to some but Leone left a long-lasting impression on all of cinema itself.
Great plot. Great acting. Great music.  And one of the very Great endings to a Great film.  The last 20 minutes are just fantastic cinema.

Clint Eastwood has done justice to the revisionist view of the wild west and the lives of the bounty hunters. While the protagonist (Will Munny) repent the actions of his past but the dire straits lead him to the abyss (killing spree) once again. The gory details in the climax have made any possible romanticism of the wild west impossible. Rightly so this movie has been added to the National Film Registry of US for being culturally important while portraying the wild west objectively.

"The Wolf of Wall Street" stands as a testament to the storytelling power of cinema when it intersects with real-life events. Its basis in truth allows the audience to not only witness the extremes of human behavior but also to reflect on the broader implications and lessons that extend beyond the screen.

"The Wolf of Wall Street" is infectiously entertaining. It is probably the funniest movie I have seen all year with witty dialogue, over the top characters, and filled with energy that bleeds off the screen. Between all the fun however,  there is also a story about addiction and how it can cause a downward spiral in your life whether it be drugs, money, or power.

The final film from Martin Scorsese is a poignant departure from his signature crime narratives, offering a sensitive exploration that delves into the injustice faced by American Indigenous communities. Clocking in at an immersive 3 1/2 hours, Scorsese skillfully weaves a tapestry of storytelling, complemented by a mesmerizing score that captivates the audience's attention throughout.

There should've been a few better pathways to tie this film together, but it's worth watching. At it's core, it's a metaphysical take on aging, relationships and perceptions of how life is supposed to play out.

The film centers around Barbie, voiced by a charismatic and talented actress, as she embarks on a thrilling adventure in a magical world. The animation is a visual treat, with vibrant colors and attention to detail, making it an absolute joy to watch. From the whimsical landscapes to the meticulously designed Barbie dolls and their accessories, the animation breathes life into the beloved toys, making them leap off the screen with charm and charisma.

Oppenheimer (2023) is an extraordinary film that captivated my senses from start to finish. This historical drama, directed by the brilliant Christopher Nolan, weaves a mesmerizing narrative that delves deep into the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant physicist whose work changed the course of history during World War II.

Possibly the best Christopher Nolan script ever. The story is expertly crafted. The dialog flows in a natural, unpretentious manner, and yet every sentence is poetic while containing information and at times humour within its sentence structure.  Although there is a large chunk of physics discussions, he manages to convert them to laymen's terms while making the words sound believable coming out of a scientist's mouth.

A best film fallout in mission impossible franchise which has great screenplay, direction, cinematography, stunt choreographer,Bgm.Realy Christopher sir did an incredible work in my opinion he is one of the best hollywood director who also wrote screenplay.Tom sir is one of the finest actors in this world who at this stage of age amazed his fans and audience across the world his energetic acting and performance.

This Tarantino magic is truly unique; like nothing else in the film industry. It takes a deep journey into the lives of two men looking for their place of fame in Hollywood; all masterfully complimented with outstanding filming, talented acting, and a mind-blowing production set that deserves in full the awards it has received due to its time period accuracy.
Interesting movie. Plenty of action. Train scene was a tad unbelievable. Great storyline. Great acting. Never expected the ending.

The Godfather 2 is a brilliant movie. From Vito's backstory to Michael's present day problems, this movie has so much to offer and it was one I definitely couldn't refuse. I enjoyed the new characters presented such as Pentangeli and Hyman Roth. Of course, Al Pacino's acting was brilliant (still don't understand why he didn't win an Oscar for his performance) and De Niro didn't disappoint either as young Vito.

When I watched this movie I was amazed how Robert de Niro nailed the role of Don Vito Corleone. It could be a pressure for any actor to play a role which has previously played by a famous and good actor before and much problem to play younger Vito was that it was played by the god of cinema: Marlon Brando but Bob De niro didn't hesitate or felt under pressure for a single moment in the movie. And some times he was even better than brando himself.
Yes, more madness, mayhem, scandal, and intrigue from the Corleone family.

The Godfather 3 is not a terrible movie, this movie is by far the weakest of the 3 movies, but if you watch Godfather 1 and 2, before Godfather 3 the movie plotline for Godfather 3 will make sense. I do feel however waiting 16 years to finally finish the trilogy was bit excessive, if I had to speculate, I believe Francis Ford Coppola never intended to make a third Godfather movie, also casting his daughter Sofia as Mary, Michael Corleone's daughter was a travesty.

The Irishman is one of the finest films of the decade, one of the finest films of Martin Scorsese, one of the finest films ever made. I feel like there's so much to say about this film but no words could ever capture the brilliance of this film. I have seen it twice now and I must say feelings towards certain scenes change as you watch it again. I could now appreciate the final hour of the film much more which communicates the futility and bleakness of the inevitable fate that is knocking right at the door of these men.

Such a pleasure to watch the incredible acting talents of Robert DeNiro and Al Pacino in this very gripping movie! Robert DeNiro was hypnotizing - you couldn't take your eyes off the screen when he was in the frame. Al Pacino knows exactly how to get you on his side and to watch these two interact on the screen together is to watch the two very best (male) actors on the screen today. Pesci was riveting, so good as the crime boss.

A very cool, slick movie with a lot of class. It's become the benchmark for heist movies. It's been inspired by several classics and has also been an inspiration for so many others. The funny thing about Ocean's Eleven is there's nothing truly outstanding about any one aspect of the movie; nothing that will blow you away. However, everything is put together perfectly.

It's a lovely classical film that can be fully appreciated for its craftsmanship. The director, Martin Scorsese, has maintained a particular style of filmmaking from the olden days to the present. The gangster theme of the movie is very engaging. The story and plot are superb; they include twists that make it interesting and arouse curiosity.

A film which I have been meaning to watch for years and now i finally have. De Niro plays his role to perfection of the character they where trying to portray. Watching him makes you feel agitated by the way he responds to people, it’s as though he makes you feel his frustration. Would recommend a watch if you’ve not seen it before all though I will add it’s not a film you would feel the need to watch a second time in my opinion.

Choosing a favorite movie has always been difficult for me. I like different films for different reasons and choosing a single favorite seems to undermine what makes movies unique. However, Heat what comes to mine when I’m asked to name my favorite movie.

Film could have been called Pacino v De Niro as the two produce a masterclass of acting from start to finish. They face off against each other over a coffee which is a delight for fans of either acting legend. Great ensemble supporting cast especially Val Kilmer and Jon Voight. A young Natalie Portman puts in a great turn too. I would just give top billing to De Niro.

This movie is definitely not being like an usual crime-drama and those expecting at typical Scorsese classic are also wrong to do so. It's one of the earliest movies out of his career and perhaps you should see this movie more as a test-case for his future crime epics. In that regard alone this movie is already being an interesting and significant watch.

This film without a shadow of a doubt features the greatest acted scene in cinematic history. De Niro and Walken Russian roulette scene cannot be surpassed. The film itself may seem slow and testing but when you make the effort to watch it all from beginning to end you will realise its an absolute masterpiece of filming and acting.

The game of Russian roulette serves as a powerful metaphor for the very nature of war. Some return apparently unscathed some return missing limbs some return missing their sanity and some never return at all. Like gambling it is 'the luck of the draw'. The movie is carefully constructed to illustrate this point.

Following the vapidness that is the recent technicolor yawn of “superhero” films in the Marvel franchise, where the characters are often clumsily thrown together, it’s nice to see a stand-alone character, this time from the DC universe, given proper, serious biopic treatment by director and co-writer, Todd Phillips. The enigmatic Joaquin Phoenix stars as Arthur Fleck, an ill-fated wannabe comedian bullied by those around him and afflicted with a condition whereby he lets out an uncontrollable, maniacal laugh at the most inappropriate of moments.
